items.title: Why does "speed" only accept slow as argument?
items.body:
I was reading [the official doc.](https://buildmedia.readthedocs.org/media/pdf/gtts/latest/gtts.pdf) because I need to speed up the gTTS voice for a little project, but it seems impossible to do.

I also tried [AudioSegment](https://pypi.org/project/pydub/), but it's not affecting the voice at all, returning an error:

`'NoneType' object has no attribute '_spawn'
`

Can you add argument "fast" please? 

EDIT: I read a bunch of ppl asking for it, would it be difficult to implement?

items.title: Does gTTS-cli have `auto detect language` feature?
items.body:
Does `gTTS-cli` have auto detect language feature?

Say for example I pass language string other than English, Can `gtts-cli` detect the language?

Example:
```
stringLang = `தமிழக பாஜ\., தலைவராக இருந்த தமிழிசை சவுந்தரராஜன், கடந்த ஆகஸ்ட் மாதம் தெலுங்கானா கவர்னராக நியமிக்கப்பட்டார்\. அவர் தமிழக பா\.ஜ\., தலைவர் பதவியை ராஜினாமா செய்தார்\. இதனால், கடந்த மூன்று மாதங்களுக்கு மேலாக மாநில பாஜ\., தலைவர் பதவி காலியாக இருந்து வருகிறது\.`
```

items.title: Japanese wa and ha mixup
items.body:
Pronounces "ha" as "wa" in はい(hai) even though it's not being used as a particle in this instance.

A solution could be to add a special rule to pronounce "は” characters as "ha" if it is the very first letter in a sentence (i.e. if the previous character was nothing or "。") as starting a sentence with "はい” is relatively common but starting a sentence with a particle typically isn't done (as far as I know).

This would also allow us to force a "wa" to be a "ha" just by placing a "。” if we need to in certain situations as we can always force a "wa" with わ but we have no way to force a "ha" (as far as I know)

Forcing a "wa" or "ha" with typically unused characters like "\は" and "/は" would be nice too because we could store our data to be pronounced as \ or / but we could parse those out easily before displaying them on the screen since you wont find them in too many Japanese sentences. I think just about any roman character other than "w" would be fine to use too but don't quote me on that.


```
        tkk_expr = re.search(".*?(TKK=.*?;)W.*?", line).group(1)
```

items.title: Greetings. I could find no other way to contact the coder for this
items.body:
Greetings and let me say thank you for your hard work. If this needs to be an issue, is there a way to control the voice outside of tempo from within gTTS? I was an engineer myself for many years before being stricken with Lewy Body Dementia, like a cross between Alzheimers and Parkinsons disease. One the things this is taking away from me is my ability to speak clearly so I am using what is left of my engineers brain to quickly come up with a system using gTTS to allow myself and others in my same spot to speak clearly when its most needed. This will really help us, probably in ways that you never imagined when coming up with this. One of the bad parts of my aphasia (difficulty speaking) is that its a defect in language processing, not motor skills or anything else, which is why even sign-language people can have aphasia and not "speak". One of the stretch goals is to use a Python gesture reading library to build like a symbolic lookup to a personal DB of phrases/phrase fragments to speak. IOW using gestures and muscle memory to overcome primary language loss. I have about a year to have it working....once again, thank you and if you have questions, like I said this is the only way I could find to contact you. My email addy is coeusprime@gmail.com.

Cheers for some great work...

Jeff Cobb

items.title: Installing doesn't work because of unicode issue in README.rst
items.body:
Tried to install using pip3 and pip. I'm using Arch Linux.

```
sudo pip3 install gTTS
Collecting gTTS
  Using cached https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/eb/de/a932d79e20542a61649b80fc74798cce27677ba72507d55afa578f019379/gTTS-2.0.0.tar.gz
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pip-install-11a_6hmq/gTTS/setup.py", line 19, in <module>
        long_description=open('README.rst').read(),
      File "/usr/lib/python3.6/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode
        return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]
    UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc2 in position 1125: ordinal not in range(128)
    
    ----------------------------------------
Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip-install-11a_6hmq/gTTS/
```

As a workaround I cloned the repo and edited the setup.py file to set `long_description` to a string instead of having it read from the file. This appears to of have worked as a workaround and it installed fine.

items.title: Punctuation is wrong with longer text
items.body:
When using the following command, the translation is right:
`gtts-cli "It is sunday 18 march. Outside it is 0.6 degrees. This is a test."  -l 'en' -o /tmp/message.mp3`

It is spoken out as "zero point 6 degrees".

When using the following command, the translation is wrong:

`gtts-cli "It is sunday 18 march. Outside it is 0.6 degrees. This is a long long long long long long long long long long long  test."  -l 'en' -o /tmp/message.mp3`
 
It is spoken out as "zero 6 degrees".

I think because the text is broken in pieces by this software. Probably when it encounters a period.
When using floating numbers this is not working the right way.

When pasting long text with floating points in it in google translate, it is working as expected.

Can this be fixed?

items.body:
Hello,

While looking through [this question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47564452/recursionerror-when-using-gtts-on-python) , I was looking at the punctuation in your code and the chinese language test in your tests.  The Chinese comma (`"，"`) seems to missing from the punctuation in `_tokenize`, [here](https://github.com/pndurette/gTTS/blob/b48e7a5d7bbcff1b00003d8b3b6fda8ddd6b69d0/gtts/tts.py#L162). Since Chinese rarely uses periods or spaces, it was entirely possible that he was getting a maximum recursion error by have a space with a combination of 99 characters and commas.  I thought I would let you know as I can't imagine the fix requires more than inserting that one character into the list.

items.title: How to append to save mp3 file?
items.body:
Typical step to generate a speech file (mp3) from text is :

from gtts import gTTS
tts = gTTS(text='Hello', lang='en', slow=True)
tts.save("hello.mp3")

if I cannot give all text at once, how can I append to save mp3 file?
For example:
from gtts import gTTS
tts1 = gTTS(text='Hello', lang='en', slow=True)
tts2 = gTTS(text='World', lang='en', slow=True)

How to tts2 append to tts1 to write speech tts1 and tts2 into save file?

items.title: Encoding error (non ascii characters are not valid in gTTS())
items.body:
Hello I recently found this new amazing project. Cangratulations!!! I found an error while using a file with spanish text in it.

This is the error message:
`'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xbf' in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)
`
The text in the input file:
¿Cómo sabes que amas a alguien?  Filosofía Martha Nussbaum Incomplegencia Teorema de la Verdad del Corazón, de Platón a Proust.

The command:
`gtts-cli -o test.mp3 -f test.txt -l 'es'
`
I am not an expert with codecs and this stuff, I added this lines to gtts-cli.py:

 ```
# encoding=utf8
reload(sys)
sys.setdefaultencoding('utf8')
```


And it worked well, however I don't know if it's the optimal solution.
